reviewText: This DVD should've been a classic music video collection of the original Molly Hatchet during the life of Danny Joe Brown. Danny Joe Brown was Molly Hatchet & he still is in every fan's memory & as long as there is  Molly Hatchet! Danny Joe Brown will not be forgotten.
summary: It should've been the Original band with Danny Joe
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE GOODThe tunes are awesome and powerful. True Hatchet talent all the way.THE BADI kept the audio CD that comes with, but tossed the DVD. Bobby Ingram looks like a clone between Goldie Hawn and Chuck Norris [think I'm kiddin? look], but all the stupid showmanship gets old right from the get-go. I thought I was watching a Van Halen show, not a so-called 'down-home boys' group. And McCormack is CONSTANTLY prompting the audience to "MAKE SOME F'in NOISE!!!!" every four minutes. I got tired of that - real fast. EVERY SONG! Give us a break already.The show screams "DIG ME! SEE ME! ME! ME! ME!" from those two all the way. I have received the live 'Flirtin' DVD also but am too skeered to watch it. I'm afraid I'll cop a bad attitude to a band I've loved since their creation.
summary: Keep the audio disc - toss the DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: MOLLY HATCHET ROCKS ON THIS CONCERT DVD!!! This is modern Molly Hatchet performing at their very best. This was filmed in Hamburg, Germany outside on the banks of a river, before a packed enthusiatic crowd. I have seen other Molly Hatchet concert dvds, but this is probably the best one. Molly Hatchet is one of those "Lynyrd Skynyrd" related Jacksonville, Florida, southern rock bands.The line up consists of (I don't know all the names): A Lead Singer who is an excellent enthusiatic lead man, Bobby Ingram on lead guitar (this guy can really play, he also has a degree in accounting, the lead singer calls him the best guitar player alive), there is another guitar player, a bass guitar player, keyboard player, and drum player.The concert consists of 20 songs with a running time of approximately 125 minutes.  They play all their classics. Some highlights include: "Gator Country" (this is their "Sweet Home Alabama" or "the South's gonna do it again", -it describes why Florida is so great, and it name checks other Southern Rock Bands, it ends with Bobby Ingram playing "Dixie" with the lead singer holding a Rebel Flag behind him), "Moonlight Dancin on a Bayou", "Fall of the Peacemakers" (dedicated to our prisoners of war, POWs,and MIA's and our U.S.A. military personnel), "Beatin the Odds", "Son of the South", "The Rainbow Bridge", and an excellent guitar solo by Bobby Ingram which leads into their CLASSIC COVER VERSION of the Allman Brothers Band "Dreams" Molly Hatchet's version is very different from the Allman Brother's version - it is very UPBEAT AND ENTERGETIC and contains some excellent guitar play by Bobby Ingram, the entire band "JAMS" on this one, it's just an outstanding performance, which words which can't describe, and the concert ends with their classic song and performance of "Flirtin with Disater" which is a southern rock anthem.There is significant bonus material, which includes an extensive interview with Bobby Ingram.This is an excellent Southern Rock concert dvd that is very entertaining, very well performed, and very enjoyable to watch and enjoy, and therefore I highly recommend it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ...Bobby Ingram! I am a Molly Hatchet fan, so Hearing these songs performed live is always a treat, even if it is by, what amounts to me as, The Molly Hatchet Tribute Show - Starring Bobby Ingram.The film crew did a great job capturing the band live in a setting very fitting for a Hatchet concert, a Harley sponsored fest in Hamburg, Germany. The sound quality is very good as well, and in these areas I was very happy with the dvd. The choices of material for the show were spot on as well, covering the favorite old original MH classics and a good representation of the latter day stuff as well.Here's my beef with the situation. At the time of this video recording, there was not a single original member in the band. John Galvin, the keyboardist, is the longest standing member here (original member Dave Hlubek has since rejoined the band, coming back in 2005, the year after this show was performed}. Galvin joined the band around 1984. Ingram, who seems to be the boss now, replaced Hlubek around 1987, debuting on the 1989 "Lightning Strikes Twice" lp, quite a few years from the bands first release in 1978.Original vocalist Danny Joe Brown ultimately had to leave the band due to health issues which eventually caused his death. I've read that current singer Phil McCormack was chosen by Brown himself to take over the vocal chores. McCormack sounds incredibly like DJB and if Brown HAD to be replaced, then McCormack was a worthy choice. I don't like the way Ingram is played up as the darling of the band - I think its silly the way McCormack panders to him while the rest of the band, especially the bass player and second guitarist, are ignored as if they aren't even there.Call me grumpy, but it annoys me. Tony Iommi got bitch-slapped left and right for dragging the Black Sabbath name thru the mire for years as the only original member. These bands, Hatchet, the current Marshall Tucker Band (singer Doug Gray the ONLY original member now), and most ghastly, the current Lynyrd Skynyrd line-up (Gary Rossington, the only original- and no I don't count Medlocke. He wasn't on "Pronounced...", "Second Helping", "Nuthin Fancy" or anything else until the mid-90's)are ALL too far removed from the original line-ups and it just becomes and cash cow at that point. I understand a member quits sometimes and ya replace them and move on, but Jeeez...c'mon guys. I KNOW the music is still played well, and its great to hear them played by a band with the name, at least, but for me, its nothing more than a very expensive "tribute band". Buy  this dvd if you like the music, because the music is there, but it is NOT played by any of the guys that made you like 'em to start with. And try to ignore the fact that Ingram and McCormack seem to be a little sweet on each other.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, Amazon needs to correct its CD / DVD track listings. W-A-Y off. The hot spots: Bounty Hunter, Fall Of The Peacemakers, Devil's Canyon, Beatin' The Odds, and Dreams I'll Never See alternate betweene pure bursts of adrenaline and bar-band lagging. Why the band decided that the coda to "Layla" was a fitting instrumental break for Molly Hatchet I'll never know (other than the fact that Duane Allman was a Domino...a forced "Southern Rock" connection, perhaps). You will hear a noticeable tempo shift in "Dreams"...fatigue at the end of the set, sloppiness, or something else? Finally, Phil McCormack's between-song patter is forced and painful. When he orders "Grandma" to "get up" for the SECOND time in "Dreams," it's a real groaner. The disc carries a parental advisory as the result of Phil repeatedly using "the F word" in an attempt to pump up the audience. If you want a hot CD by this edition of the band, get "Silent Reign Of Heroes." As far as this CD-DVD combo goes, it's a rock-solid 2 star effort.
summary: A few hot moments that are the exception to the rule
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wasn't under any illusions when I purchased this cd/dvd compilation last year. I knew that Molly Hatchet had basically died years ago with Danny Joe Brown, Duane Roland and as other members left the band. I bought this set because I had first heard the "NEW" Molly Hatchet via some bootleg recordings. Frankly, I was impressed to hear just how much the band still sounded like Molly Hatchet. I think Phil McCormick was the perfect replacement for Danny Joe Brown. No, he doesn't have the depth vocally of DJB but he sure sounds a lot like the guy, even if he is trying to sound like him. Phil is a very good lead singer for this band. Bobby Ingram who is the brains of this band, and also a guitarist came along in the mid 80's. Bobby wasn't in the early band but he was around in one of the many latter incarnations of the band.As a concert the video and sound are quite good. The crowd is quite sparse though. I guess the one thing that I must admit is somewhat lacking is the loss of one guitarist. This incarnation of the band only has two guitarists and Bobby is asked about this in an interview portion, which is also quite good and comprehensive. If you want to see Dave Hlubek with the band buy the 2008 dvd. However, I'll warn you in advance that Dave is a frightful sight to see these days. Is it any wonder he has lost some guitar chops considering how fat he has become. I have also googled pictures of Phil McCormick and it appears that his weight goes up and down all the time. It's weird.I probably appreciate this band more because I am from Jacksonville, FL, the birthplace of the band. To me this band is a lot more legit that Skynyrd is these days. This band sounds more like the original band whereas Skynyrd just can't cut it anymore, not imo at least.
summary: Bobby Ingram keeps the Molly Hatchet franchise alive.
Title: N/A

reviewText: LIVE IN HAMBURG is a great CD/DVD by Molly Hatchet, featuring several songs from WARRIORS OF THE RAINBOW BRIDGE. The CD equals the great LOCKED AND LOADED, eliminating some of the filler that clogged the previous live CD, but misses the timelees anthem "Flirtin' With Disaster", which IS on LOCKED AND LOADED, as well as on the DVD. The band members' advocacies of sanctions against Indonesia in retaliation for that country's trumped-up 2005 drug-smuggling conviction of a young Australian tourist, capital punishment for kidnappers, and increased funding for law enforcement, make LIVE IN HAMBURG an essential purchase for your ears, your eyes, AND your conscience.
Title: N/A
